unnormalised: ## My Adventures in the Land of "Exact Change, Please!"
normalised: ## My Adventures in the Land of "Exact Change, Please!"

unnormalised: So, you think you're a master of the financial universe, eh? You've got your SIPs, your MF, your cryptocurrency investments... all those fancy acronyms that make you sound like a genius at Diwali parties. Well, let me tell you, all that sophistication goes right out the window the moment you step into the real world of Indian banking and cash transactions.
normalised: So, you think you're a master of the financial universe, eh? You've got your S-I-P-s, your M-F, your cryptocurrency investments... all those fancy acronyms that make you sound like a genius at Diwali parties. Well, let me tell you, all that sophistication goes right out the window the moment you step into the real world of Indian banking and cash transactions.

unnormalised: My recent escapade involved a simple mission: deposit ₹5000 into my account at the local branch of State Bank of India (SBI). Sounds easy, right? Famous last words, my friend.
normalised: My recent escapade involved a simple mission: deposit rupee five thousand into my account at the local branch of State Bank of India (S-B-I). Sounds easy, right? Famous last words, my friend.

unnormalised: First hurdle: the queue. Now, I've faced longer lines waiting for butter chicken at a wedding buffet, but this was different. This was a queue imbued with the solemnity of a pilgrimage. People were clutching crumpled notes like sacred relics, whispering fervent prayers for the teller to accept their deposit slip.

unnormalised: I finally reached the counter, armed with my deposit slip and a wad of crispy, freshly-minted ₹500 notes. "Good morning," I chirped, "I'd like to deposit ₹5000, please." The teller, a seasoned veteran of countless cash transactions, looked at me with the weary wisdom of a thousand lifetimes. "Exact change, please?" she asked, her voice devoid of emotion.
normalised: I finally reached the counter, armed with my deposit slip and a wad of crispy, freshly-minted rupee five hundred notes. "Good morning," I chirped, "I'd like to deposit rupee five thousand, please." The teller, a seasoned veteran of countless cash transactions, looked at me with the weary wisdom of a thousand lifetimes. "Exact change, please?" she asked, her voice devoid of emotion.

unnormalised: Exact change? I stared at her blankly. I had five pristine ₹1000 notes. What was the problem? Apparently, the bank was suffering from a mysterious "shortage of small denomination notes." A shortage that seemed to affect everyone but the guy selling peanuts outside the branch who, I’m willing to bet, had a secret stash of ₹10 notes rivalling Fort Knox.

A shortage that seemed to affect everyone but the guy selling peanuts outside the branch who, I’m willing to bet, had a secret stash of rupee ten notes rivalling Fort Knox.

unnormalised: Undeterred (and slightly sweating), I ventured outside to break my ₹1000 notes. "Excuse me, bhai," I asked a nearby auto-rickshaw driver, "can you give me change for a thousand?" He sized me up, probably calculating how much he could overcharge me for a short ride, before declaring, "Sorry, madam, no change. Everyone wants change these days!"

unnormalised: I tried the peanut vendor. Same story. The tea stall owner looked at me like I'd asked him to convert lead into gold. I was beginning to suspect that the "shortage of small denomination notes" was a nationwide conspiracy orchestrated by the black market mafia. Maybe I should call CBI?

unnormalised: Dejected, I returned to the bank, defeated. "Still no change?" the teller asked, with a hint of amusement in her eyes. I shook my head. "Okay," she sighed, "give me the ₹5000. But next time, please bring exact change!"
normalised: Dejected, I returned to the bank, defeated. "Still no change?" the teller asked, with a hint of amusement in her eyes. I shook my head. "Okay," she sighed, "give me the rupee five thousand. But next time, please bring exact change!"

unnormalised: So, there you have it. My thrilling adventure in the land of "Exact Change, Please!" A valuable lesson learned: in India, even the simplest banking transaction can turn into a quest worthy of Indiana Jones. Always carry a pocketful of ₹10, ₹20, and ₹50 notes. Your sanity (and your bank teller) will thank you. And maybe, just maybe, you'll be prepared for the inevitable moment when you need to pay ₹27 for your chai and the vendor tells you he only has change for ₹100. Good luck!
